# Access or assign natural mortality at age

This function can be used to access or assign the natural mortality at
age in an
[`lhm`](https://github.com/biomass-dynamic-models/lhm/reference/lhm-class.md)
object.

Assignment can be of a list or numeric vector. When a list is assigned
it should contain a value for `mu`, which is the mean natural mortality
at age and may or may not be constant across ages.

If the list also contains `cv` then log-normal uncertainty is added
around the mortality at age. If the list contains `range` then the
uncertainty is bounded at these values. If `range` is provided but not
`cv`, and if mortality is constant across ages, then a uniform
uncertainy is implemented.

## Usage

``` r
nmort(object, ...)

# S4 method for class 'lhm'
nmort(object)

nmort(object) <- value

# S4 method for class 'lhm,list'
nmort(object) <- value

# S4 method for class 'lhm,numeric'
nmort(object) <- value
```

## Arguments

- object:

  a
  [`lhm`](https://github.com/biomass-dynamic-models/lhm/reference/lhm-class.md)
  object

- ...:

  arguments to generic function

- value:

  either a named `list` or `numeric` vector

  `numeric`

  :   a single numeric or vector of values

  `list`

  :   a list object containing the components `mu`, `cv` and `range`

  `mu`

  :   a single numeric or vector of values representing the mean natural
      mortality

  `cv`

  :   optional single numeric value representing the coefficient of
      variation

  `range`

  :   optional vector of length two containing the lower and upper
      bounds

## Value

Accessor function returns a matrix of maturity at age across iterations.
Assignment function populates the matrix across iterations.

## Examples

``` r
# M at age vector input
dat <- lhm(ainf = 10,iter=1)
nmort(dat) <- c(0.1,0.1,0.2)
nmort(dat)
#>       [,1]
#>  [1,]  0.1
#>  [2,]  0.1
#>  [3,]  0.2
#>  [4,]  0.2
#>  [5,]  0.2
#>  [6,]  0.2
#>  [7,]  0.2
#>  [8,]  0.2
#>  [9,]  0.2
#> [10,]  0.2

# constant M with log-normal uncertainty
dat <- lhm(ainf=10, iter = 20)
nmort(dat) <- list(mu = 0.2, cv = 0.25)
nmort(dat)
#>            [,1]      [,2]     [,3]      [,4]      [,5]     [,6]      [,7]
#>  [1,] 0.2221569 0.1108381 0.375593 0.1775167 0.2044938 0.252783 0.1647199
#>  [2,] 0.2221569 0.1108381 0.375593 0.1775167 0.2044938 0.252783 0.1647199
#>  [3,] 0.2221569 0.1108381 0.375593 0.1775167 0.2044938 0.252783 0.1647199

#> [10,] 0.2221569 0.1108381 0.375593 0.1775167 0.2044938 0.252783 0.1647199

# constant M with bounded log-normal uncertainty
dat <- lhm(ainf = 10, iter = 20)
nmort(dat) <- list(mu = 0.2, cv = 0.5, range = c(0.1,0.3))
nmort(dat)

# constant M with uniform uncertainty
dat <- lhm(ainf = 10,iter = 20)
nmort(dat) <- list(range = c(0.1,0.3))
nmort(dat)

# M at age with log-normal uncertainty
dat <- lhm(ainf=10, iter = 20)
nmort(dat) <- list(mu = c(0.1,0.1,0.2), cv = 0.25)
nmort(dat)
#>             [,1]       [,2]       [,3]      [,4]      [,5]       [,6]
#>  [1,] 0.08184549 0.08454917 0.08500587 0.1025942 0.1234423 0.09215083

# M at age with bounded log-normal uncertainty

nmort(dat) <- list(mu = c(0.1,0.1,0.2), cv = 0.25, range = c(0.1,0.3))
```
